title: Sydney Man Charged With Allegedly Threatening To Kill Anthony Albanese | 10 News
description: A Greystanes man has faced court after allegedly threatening to kill the Prime Minister, a day after the Bondi attack. Outside the court, Greg Tait claimed to be on team Australia, blowing a kiss at waiting media. title: Victorian Bushfires Worsen As Number Of Homes Destroyed Increases | 10 News
description: The number of homes destroyed in Victoria’s bushfires has dramatically increased as crews gain access to fire-ravaged areas. The fires have now burned across more than 400,000 hectares, with 770 structures damaged or destroyed. Towns in the Longwood region have been devastated, but an incredible community spirit has emerged to support those who’ve lost everything. title: Australian Palestinian Writer Launches Legal Action Against SA Premier | 10 News
description: An Australian Palestinian writer is taking legal action against the Premier over his comments, which led to her exclusion from Adelaide Writers' Week. The event has collapsed after a mass boycott, but Peter Malinauskas does not regret speaking out. title: Alex De Minaur Says He Feels Ready & Relaxed Ahead Of Australian Open | 10 News
description: Alex De Minaur says he isn't feeling the pressure ahead of his home slam. However, the world number six won't be joined in the main draw by compatriot Bernard Tomic. The 33-year-old went down in straight sets in the second round of qualifying. title: Iran Protests Victim Identified, BTS Announces World Tour, Pro-Life Group Targets Canva | 10 News+
description: Despite a complete internet shutdown, one of the victims who was shot dead during the horrific Iran protests has been identified after her family were denied a funeral and forced to bury her in a shallow grave.  Global Korean super sensations BTS have announced their first world tour in years, sending Australian fans into a frenzy.  A new ethical responsibility debate over reproductive rights has Australian company Canva in hot water after it appears they have a strong stance on the matter. title: Pro-Life Group Targets Tech Giant Canva | 10 News+
description: Australian start-up success story Canva has drawn the ire of a pro-life organisation. After Roe v Wade was overturned in 2022 in the US, Canva promised to cover the cost of travel and accommodation for staff based in America if they had to travel to receive abortion care elsewhere. Right to Life have complained the design tool offers pro-choice templates but no pre-populated designs for pro-life causes with the group questioning if the tech company should be taking sides in the debate. title: Iran Protests Death Toll Passes 2,500 As Some Victims Are Identified | 10 News+
description: The death toll of mass protests in Iran has passed 2,500, with some human rights groups’ estimates placing it as high as 20,000. One of the identified victims is Rubina Aminian, a 23-year-old fashion student shot dead by security forces. There are also reports that public executions will start today, with many of those arrested and condemned to death being teenagers and university-aged youths. US President Donald Trump has told the protesters to “take over your institutions”, vowing that “help is on the way”. title: Why Fans Are In A Frenzy Over BTS’ World Tour Announcement | 10 News+
description: BTS is the K-Pop boy band taking over the music industry right now and they’re coming to Australia for the first time since 2017. The announcement marks the band’s first world tour in years and is set to rake in more than one billion dollars with some accommodation already selling out before tickets have hit the market. 10 News+ gives you a closer look at why these stars have captured the world’s attention. title: Thousands of Victorian Students Affected In Major Government School Data Breach | 10 Late News
description: Thousands of Victorian students have had their personal information exposed in a targeted cyber-attack on government schools.  Officials say a third party broke into a school network, prompting systems to be shut down.
